reviews.review_text: If only I could give these books to my younger self. I really needed them at the time.
I started with Tales of the City - a book that was on the bookshelf at a cottage we were renting.  I am now hooked on the 7 book series - I have made it to the 3rd book, Further Tales of the City.

I love the plot, the intrigue and the characters. Mary Ann Singleton is a classic character. I also like the mystery subplot and the somewhat happy ending. Armistead Maupin is the kind of writer that I aspire to be.
This book holds up over time.  Fast paced read, makes you feel like your in San Francisco in the 70s.
Maupin's  characters really come to life.  I feel like I know them and they are friends.  The books are great!  I love them and want to continue "hanging out" with them.

ALL of Armistead Maupin's "Tales of the City" books are remarkable.  I read them when they first came out, and am now re-reading them, more for nostalgic reasons.  Maupin knows how to write characters, and he gives them each their own voice:  from the young, green Maryann Singleton from Ohio, to the fabulous over 50 year old Anna Madrigal.  The stories bring you to a time before the AIDS epidemic, but also before marriage equality, where many homosexuals were still hiding who they were ~ although not as much in San Francisco!  I would recommend these books to anyone who loves a good, quick read, but a book with substance and a good story.
As Entertaining as it was 20 years ago when I first read the book.
absolutely fantastic. Better than the first, even.

title: More Tales of the City

summary:
Book 2/9 in the Tales of the City Series

The tenants of 28 Barbary Lane have fled their cozy nest for adventures far afield. Mary Ann Singleton finds love at sea with a forgetful stranger, Mona Ramsey discovers her doppelgänger in a desert whorehouse, and Michael Tolliver bumps into his favorite gynecologist in a Mexican bar. Meanwhile, their venerable landlady takes the biggest journey of all—without ever leaving home.
story_arc:
An initial rise in good fortunes, followed
                    by a setback, but a happy ending
